overview_summary: These organizational neighbors are long-established family farm corporations with deep local roots rather than outside speculators. Both Call Farms and Norton Farms are multi-generational operations controlling large acreages and have agreed to lease land for the proposed Genesee County solar project, indicating a supportive stance driven by financial incentives. Their strong standing in the community (Call Farms is one of New York’s largest farms; Dean Norton is a former state Farm Bureau president) means their cooperation reduces the risk of organized local opposition and could help foster broader community acceptance of the development.

neighbors.name: Call Farms, Inc.
neighbors.claims: Call Farms, Inc. (dba My-T Acres) was established in 1922 and has been owned and operated by the Call family for four generations, growing into one of the largest farm enterprises in New York State [New York Senate](https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/resolutions/2019/2019-k684). The farm spans about 8,500 acres across Genesee, Orleans, and Livingston Counties, producing potatoes (for chip processors), sweet corn and other crops, and it employs roughly 30 full-time staff with extensive irrigation infrastructure in place [Genesee County Chamber of Commerce](https://members.geneseeny.com/list/member/call-lands-my-t-acres-inc-53). Call Farms, Inc. was honored as Genesee County’s 2019 Agricultural Business of the Year, reflecting its significant growth and community contributions over the years [New York Senate](https://www.nysenate.gov/legislation/resolutions/2019/2019-k684). The company has signed lease option agreements with Hecate Energy to host a 500 MW solar project (Cider Solar Farm), committing more than 1,000 acres of its farmland to the development[The Batavian](https://www.thebatavian.com/mike-pettinella/cider-solar-farm-coming-to-the-towns-of-elba-and-oakfield-sweet-to-some-hard-to).
neighbors.influence_justification: High – Fourth-generation farm owning thousands of acres; major local employer (30+ staff); well-respected family (recognized with county agricultural award) with philanthropic ties to local institutions

approach_recommendations.engage: Maintain close communication with the Call family’s leadership (e.g., Nathan Call), emphasizing the project’s benefits to their farm’s long-term stability. Acknowledge their stature in the community and address any concerns collaboratively, while avoiding pressuring them into a public spotlight given their preference for low-profile support.

neighbors.name: Norton Farms Inc
neighbors.claims: Norton Farms Inc is a fifth-generation family dairy farm based in Elba, NY, with roots dating back to 1906 (recently recognized as a Century Farm by the NYS Agricultural Society) and formally incorporated in 1983 [Ag Proud](https://www.agproud.com/articles/28803-i-belong-to-afbf-dean-norton). The company employs approximately 21 people and generates around $1.8 million in annual revenue, reflecting a substantial local agribusiness operation [Manta](https://www.manta.com/c/mtcct3y/norton-farms-inc). The farm’s principal, Dean Norton, served as President of the New York Farm Bureau for eight years (2008–2016), highlighting his significant influence in agricultural policy and local farming circles [Orleans Hub](https://orleanshub.com/ny-farm-bureau-elects-new-president/). Norton Farms Inc has signed an option to lease roughly 600 acres to Hecate Energy for the 500 MW Cider Solar Farm project, indicating the farm’s support for the development and its intent to capitalize on the stable lease income [The Batavian](https://www.thebatavian.com/mike-pettinella/cider-solar-farm-coming-to-the-towns-of-elba-and-oakfield-sweet-to-some-hard-to).
neighbors.influence_justification: High – Century-old farm family with extensive local presence; led by a former state Farm Bureau president (strong political and agricultural network); owns significant acreage and dairy operation in the community

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage Dean Norton directly, respecting his expertise and leadership in the farm community. Provide transparent, fact-based updates on project impacts and benefits to farming; gaining his continued confidence is key, as his tacit support and credibility will help prevent or defuse local opposition.
